channel.title: Scripting Languages
channel.description:
I am planning to load scripts for a project I am currently doing, which scripting language should I start learning and which is more efficient?
Out of these: Python, Lua, Ruby.
I don't know a lot about scripting languages so if someone could break that down I would love you forever<3
Thanks<333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333

item.title: Scripting Languages
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

[quote="_s, post:5, topic:390707"][quote author=Wintercanon link=topic=486616.msg3566274#msg3566274 date=1302670329]
It depends really. Are you using Java for the project? If so I’d use Ruby as JRuby has more support for the soon to be depreciated Jython.
[/quote]
depreciated? i think you were looking for deprecated :P[/quote]
Haha yes. :o

Read full topic

item.title: Scripting Languages
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

Wintercanon:

It depends really. Are you using Java for the project? If so I’d use Ruby as JRuby has more support for the soon to be depreciated Jython.

depreciated? i think you were looking for deprecated

[quote=“zyle1992, post:3, topic:390707”][quote author=Clawz fury link=topic=486616.msg3566073#msg3566073 date=1302656646]
I am planning to load scripts for a project I am currently doing, which scripting language should I start learning and which is more efficient?

Out of these: Python, Lua, Ruby.

I don’t know a lot about scripting languages so if someone could break that down I would love you forever<3

Thanks<333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333
[/quote]

Reloadable classes.[/quote]
why bother using reloadable classes? you may as well use something like Groovy if you’re really adamant to keep something similar to Java and, as with all scripts, you have the benefit of not having to recompile the script in question, just edit the file and you’re set.

if i was using a language like the ones you (OP) listed, if i was using the language on it’s own then i’d probably use either Ruby or Python since they have nice standard libraries and they’re generally nice to work with. however, if i had to embed a language into a C application i’d use Lua because it’s small and you don’t need to learn much to embed it with a big benefit that it’s fast and minimal in design and you don’t have to write much boilerplate. as for a Java application, i’d stick with either JRuby, Clojure (a Lisp dialect for the JVM) or Groovy because of Jython’s shortfallings and embedding them won’t be a problem because this is one area where i think the JVM excels. and a final notion is to research yourself and play with languages, usually one will stick out above the others.

Read full topic
